policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Understanding and using the NZISM
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The New Zealand Information Security Manual details processes and controls essential for the protection of all New Zealand Government information and systems. Controls and processes representing good practice are also provided to enhance the baseline controls. Baseline controls are minimum acceptable levels of controls and are often described as �systems hygiene�. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#Section-11965

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 1.1.64.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Understanding and using the NZISM - Non-compliance
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Controls for classified systems and information within this manual with a �MUST� or �MUST NOT� compliance requirement cannot be effectively individually risk managed by agencies without jeopardising their own, multi-agency or All-of-Government information assurance. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document/#SubSection-12064

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 1.1.65.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Understanding and using the NZISM - Justification for non-compliance
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Without sufficient justification and consideration of security risks by the system owner when seeking a dispensation, the agency head or their authorised delegate will lack the appropriate range of information to the make an informed decision on whether to accept the security risk and grant the dispensation or not. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document/#SubSection-12064

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 1.1.66.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Understanding and using the NZISM - Consultation on non-compliance
policyDefinitionGroups.description: When an agency stores information on their systems that belongs to a foreign government they have an obligation to inform and seek agreement from that third party when they do not apply all appropriate controls in this manual. These third parties will place reliance on the application of controls from the NZISM. If the agency fails to implement all appropriate controls, the third party will be unaware that their information may have been placed at a heightened risk of compromise. As such, the third party is denied the opportunity to consider their own additional risk mitigation measures for their information in light of the agency�s desire to risk manage controls from this manual. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document/#SubSection-12064

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Understanding and using the NZISM - All-of-Government Systems
policyDefinitionGroups.description: All-of-Government systems, because they are connected to multiple agencies, have the potential to cause significant and widespread disruption should system failures, cyber-attacks or other incidents occur. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document/#SubSection-12064

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 1.1.68.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Understanding and using the NZISM - Reviewing non-compliance
policyDefinitionGroups.description: As part of the process of providing justification for a dispensation to the Accreditation Authority, an assessment of the degree of compliance, identification of areas of non-compliance and determination of residual security risk is undertaken by the agency or lead agency. This assessment is based on the risk environment at the time the dispensation is sought. As the risk environment will continue to evolve over time it is important that agencies revisit the assessment on an annual basis and update it according to the current risk environment, and if necessary reverse any decisions to grant a dispensation if the security risk is no longer of an acceptable level. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document/#SubSection-12064

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Using Cloud Services - Zero Trust

Zero Trust is becoming the de-facto approach to ICT system security and is recommended by GCSB as the approach agencies should take, particularly as part of the adoption of cloud services.Zero Trust is a set of principles and outcomes, not an architecture or a solution.� You cannot �buy� Zero Trust.Zero Trust is compatible with other ICT outcomes, such as improved access to information, increased agility and better security.Key aspects of Zero Trust focus on:
Visibility (through telemetry) and analytics of how services are functioning � this comes through as focus on monitoring, event gathering and machine learning based analysis; and
Automation of service delivery and security actions.

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Using Cloud Services - Risk Assessment
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The adoption of cloud technologies will introduce a wide range of technology and information system risks in addition to the risks that already exist for agency systems. policyDefinitionGroups.description: The development of an accreditation framework within the agency will ensure that accreditation activities are conducted in a repeatable and consistent manner across the agency and that consistency across government systems is maintained. This requirement is a fundamental part of a robust governance model and provides a sound process to demonstrate good governance of information systems. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document/#SubSection-12598

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 4.4.5.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Accreditation Framework - Accreditation
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Accreditation ensures that either sufficient security measures have been put in place to protect information that is processed, stored or communicated by the system or that deficiencies in such measures have been identified, assessed and acknowledged by an appropriate authority. As such, when systems are awarded accreditation the Accreditation Authority accepts that the residual security risks relating to the system are appropriate for the information that it processes, stores or communicates. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document/#SubSection-12598

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Accreditation Framework - Due diligence
policyDefinitionGroups.description: When an agency is connecting a system to another party they need to be aware of the security measures the other party has implemented to protect their information. More importantly, the agency needs to know where the other party may have varied from controls in this manual. policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Accreditation Framework - Processing restrictions
policyDefinitionGroups.description: When security is applied to systems, protective measures are put in place based on the highest classification that will be processed, stored or communicated by the system. As such, any classified information placed on the system above the level for which it has been accredited will receive an inappropriate level of protection and could be exposed to a greater risk of compromise. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document/#SubSection-12598

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Accreditation Framework - Requirement for New Zealand control
policyDefinitionGroups.description: NZEO systems process, store and communicate information that is particularly sensitive to the government of New Zealand. When agencies are dealing with New Zealand Eyes Only (NZEO) information they need to be aware of the requirement for a New Zealand national to remain in control of the system and information at all times. It is, therefore, essential that control of such systems is maintained by New Zealand citizens working for the government of New Zealand. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document/#SubSection-12598

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Documentation Fundamentals - Information Security Policy (SecPol)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The SecPol is an essential part of information security documentation as it outlines the high-level policy objectives. The SecPol can form part of the overall agency security policy. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document/#SubSection-12695

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Documentation Fundamentals - System Security Plan (SSP)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The SSP describes the implementation and operation of controls within the system derived from the NZISM and the SRMP. policyDefinitionGroups.name: 5.1.11.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Documentation Fundamentals - Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: SOPs provide step-by-step guides to undertaking information security related tasks and processes. They provide assurance that tasks can be undertaken in a secure and repeatable manner, even by system users without strong technical knowledge of the system�s mechanics. policyDefinitionGroups.name: 5.1.12.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Documentation Fundamentals - Incident Response Plan (IRP)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The purpose of developing an IRP is to ensure that information security incidents are appropriately managed. In most situations the aim of the response will be to contain the incident and prevent the information security incident from escalating. The preservation of any evidence relating to the information security incident for criminal, forensic and process improvement purposes is also an important consideration. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document/#SubSection-12695

policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies outsourcing the development of information security documentation need to be aware of the contents of the documentation produced. policyDefinitionGroups.name: 5.3.6.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Security Risk Management Plans - Agency and system specific security risks
policyDefinitionGroups.description: While a baseline of security risks with associated levels of security risk and corresponding risk treatments are provided in this manual, agencies will almost certainly have variations to those considered during the security risk assessment. Such variations could be in the form of differing risk sources and threats, assets and vulnerabilities, or exposure and severity. In such cases an agency will need to follow its own risk management procedures to determine its risk appetite and associated risk acceptance, risk avoidance and risk tolerance thresholds. Risk owners must be identified. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document/#SubSection-12771

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 5.3.7.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Security Risk Management Plans - Contents of SRMPs
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Risks within an agency can be managed if they are not known, and if they are known, failing to treat or accept them is also a failure of risk management. For this reason SRMPs consist of two components, a security risk assessment and a corresponding treatment strategy. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document/#SubSection-12771

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 5.3.8.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Security Risk Management Plans - Agency risk management
policyDefinitionGroups.description: If an agency fails to incorporate SRMPs for systems into their wider agency risk management plan then the agency will be unable to manage risks in a coordinated and consistent manner across the agency. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document/#SubSection-12771

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 5.3.9.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Security Risk Management Plans - Risk Management standards
policyDefinitionGroups.description: For security risk management to be of true value to an agency there must be direct relevance to the specific circumstances of an agency and its systems, as well as being based on an industry recognised approach or risk management guidelines. For example, guidelines and standards produced by Standards New Zealand and the International Organization for Standardization.The Protective Security Requirements requires that agencies adopt risk management approaches in accordance with ISO 31000:2018. Refer to PSR governance requirement GOV2. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document/#SubSection-12771

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: System Security Plans - Contents of System Security Plans (SSPs)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The NZISM provides a list of controls that are potentially applicable to a system based on its classification, its functionality and the technology it is implementing. Agencies will need to determine which controls are in scope of the system and translate those controls to the SSP. Formally documenting this information ensures that standards, controls and procedures can easily be reviewed by security personnel. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13269

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 8.2.8.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Servers And Network Devices - No-lone-zones
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Areas containing particularly sensitive materials or IT equipment can be provided with additional security through the use of a designated no-lone-zone. The aim of this designation is to enforce two-person integrity, where all actions are witnessed by at least one other person. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13269

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Network Infrastructure
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Network infrastructure is protected by secure facilities and the use of encryption technologies. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#Section-13284

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 8.3.3.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Network Infrastructure - Network infrastructure in secure areas
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Network infrastructure is considered to process information being communicated across it and as such needs to meet the minimum physical security requirements for processing classified information as specified in the PSR Management protocol for physical security, with supporting document � Storage requirements for electronic information in ICT facilities. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13290

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 8.3.3.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Network Infrastructure - Network infrastructure in secure areas
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Network infrastructure is considered to process information being communicated across it and as such needs to meet the minimum physical security requirements for processing classified information as specified in the PSR Management protocol for physical security, with supporting document � Storage requirements for electronic information in ICT facilities. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13290

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 8.3.4.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Network Infrastructure - Protecting network infrastructure
policyDefinitionGroups.description: In order to prevent tampering with patch panels, fibre distribution panels and structured wiring, any such enclosures need to be placed within at least lockable commercial cabinets. Furthermore, keys for such cabinets should not be remain in locks as this defeats the purpose of using lockable commercial cabinets in the first place. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13290

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 8.3.5.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Network Infrastructure - Network infrastructure in unsecure areas
policyDefinitionGroups.description: As agencies lose control over classified information when it is communicated over unsecure public network infrastructure or over infrastructure in unsecure areas they MUST ensure that it is encrypted to a sufficient level that if it was captured that it would be sufficiently difficult to determine the original information from the encrypted information. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13290

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: IT Equipment
policyDefinitionGroups.description: IT equipment is secured outside of normal working hours, is non-operational or when work areas are unoccupied. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#Section-13306

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 8.4.8.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: IT Equipment - Accounting for IT equipment
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Ensuring that IT equipment containing media is accounted for by using asset registers, equipment registers, operational & configuration records and regular audits will assist in preventing loss or theft, or in the cases of loss or theft, alerting appropriate authorities to its loss or theft. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13319

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 8.4.9.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: IT Equipment - Processing requirements
policyDefinitionGroups.description: As the media within IT equipment takes on the classification of the information it is processing, the area that it is used within needs to be certified to a level that is appropriate for the classification of that information. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13319

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 8.4.10.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: IT Equipment - Storage requirements
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The PSR states that either Class C, B or A secure rooms or Class C, B or A security containers or lockable commercial cabinets can be used to meet physical security requirements for the storage of IT equipment containing media. The class of secure room or security container will depend on the physical security certification of the surrounding area and the classification of the information. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13319

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 8.4.11.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: IT Equipment - Securing non-volatile media for storage
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The use of techniques to prevent the storage of classified information on non-volatile media and processes to delete temporary data at logoff or shutdown may sound secure but there is no guarantee that they will always work effectively or will not be bypassed in unexpected circumstances such as a loss of power. As such, agencies need to consider these risks when implementing such a solution. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13319

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 8.4.12.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: IT Equipment - Securing volatile media for storage
policyDefinitionGroups.description:
If agencies need to conduct a security risk assessment as part of the procedure for storing IT equipment containing media during non-operation hours, they should consider security risks such as:
an attacker gaining access to the IT equipment immediately after power is removed and accessing the contents of volatile media to recover encryption keys or parts thereof. This is sometimes described as a data remanence attack;
extreme environmental conditions causing data to remain in volatile media for extended periods after the removal of power; and
the physical security of the locations in which the IT equipment will reside.
 https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13319

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 8.4.13.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: IT Equipment - Encrypting media within IT equipment
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Current industry good practice is to encrypt all media within IT equipment. Newer operating systems provide this functionality and older operating systems can be supported with the use of open source or proprietary applications. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13319

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Tamper Evident Seals
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Tamper evident seals and associated auditing processes identify attempts to bypass the physical security of systems and their infrastructure. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#Section-13339

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 8.5.3.C.03.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Tamper Evident Seals - Recording seal usage
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Recording information about seals in a register and on which asset they are used assists in reducing the security risk that seals could be substituted without security personnel being aware of the change. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13345

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 8.5.3.C.04.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Tamper Evident Seals - Recording seal usage
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Recording information about seals in a register and on which asset they are used assists in reducing the security risk that seals could be substituted without security personnel being aware of the change. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13345

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 8.5.4.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Tamper Evident Seals - Purchasing seals
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Using uniquely numbered seals ensures that a seal can be uniquely mapped to an asset. This assists security personnel in reducing the security risk that seals could be replaced without anyone being aware of the change. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13345

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 8.5.4.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Tamper Evident Seals - Purchasing seals
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Using uniquely numbered seals ensures that a seal can be uniquely mapped to an asset. This assists security personnel in reducing the security risk that seals could be replaced without anyone being aware of the change. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13345

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 8.5.4.C.03.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Tamper Evident Seals - Purchasing seals
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Using uniquely numbered seals ensures that a seal can be uniquely mapped to an asset. This assists security personnel in reducing the security risk that seals could be replaced without anyone being aware of the change. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13345

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 8.5.5.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Tamper Evident Seals - Reviewing seal usage
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Users of assets with seals should be encouraged to randomly check the integrity of the seals and to report any concerns to security personnel. In addition, conducting at least annual reviews will allow for detection of any tampering to an asset and ensure that the correct seal is located on the correct asset. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13345

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Information Security Awareness and Training
policyDefinitionGroups.description: A security culture�is fostered through induction training and ongoing security education tailored to roles, responsibilities, changing threat environment and sensitivity of information, systems and operations. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#Section-13361

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.1.4.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Information Security Awareness and Training - Information security awareness and training responsibility
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agency management is responsible for ensuring that an appropriate information security awareness and a training program is provided for all personnel. Without management support, security personnel might not have sufficient resources to facilitate awareness and training for other personnel. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13369

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.1.5.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Information Security Awareness and Training - Information security awareness and training

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.1.5.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Information Security Awareness and Training - Information security awareness and training

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.1.6.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Information Security Awareness and Training - Degree and content of information security awareness and training
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The detail, content and coverage of information security awareness and training will depend on the objectives of the organisation. Personnel with responsibilities beyond that of a general user should have tailored training to meet their needs. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13369

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.1.8.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Information Security Awareness and Training - Disclosure of information while on courses
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Government personnel attending courses with non-government personnel may not be aware of the consequences of disclosing information relating to the security of their agency�s systems. Raising awareness of such consequences in personnel will assist in preventing disclosures that could lead to a targeted attack being launched against an agency�s systems. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13369

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Only appropriately authorised, cleared and briefed personnel are allowed access to systems. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#Section-13391

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.2.10.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Documenting authorisations, security clearance and briefing requirements
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Ensuring that the requirements for access to a system are documented and agreed upon will assist in determining if system users have appropriate authorisations, security clearances and need-to-know to access the system. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13406

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.2.11.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Authorisation and system access
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Personnel seeking access to a system will need to have a genuine business requirement to access the system as verified by their supervisor or manager. Once a requirement to access a system is established, the system user should be given only the privileges that they need to undertake their duties. Providing all system users with privileged access when there is no such requirement can cause significant security vulnerabilities in a system. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13406

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.2.12.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Recording authorisation for personnel to access systems
policyDefinitionGroups.description: In many cases, the requirement to maintain a secure record of all personnel authorised to access a system, their user identification, who provided the authorisation and when the authorisation was granted, can be met by retaining a completed system account request form signed by the supervisor or manager of the system user. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13406

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.2.13.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Security clearance for system access
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Information classified as CONFIDENTIAL and above requires personnel to have been granted a formal security clearance before access is granted. Refer to the PSR Personnel Security Mandatory Requirements. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13406

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.2.14.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - System access briefings
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Some systems process endorsed or compartmented information. As such, unique briefings may exist that system users need to receive before being granted access to the system. All system users will require a briefing on their responsibilities on access to and use of the system to which they have been granted access to avoid inadvertent errors and security breaches. Specialised system training may also be required. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13406

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.2.15.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Access by foreign nationals to NZEO systems
policyDefinitionGroups.description: NZEO information is restricted to New Zealand nationals. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13406

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.2.15.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Access by foreign nationals to NZEO systems
policyDefinitionGroups.description: NZEO information is restricted to New Zealand nationals. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13406

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.2.16.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Access by foreign nationals to New Zealand systems
policyDefinitionGroups.description: When information from foreign nations is entrusted to the New Zealand Government, care needs to be taken to ensure that foreign nationals do not have access to such information unless it has also been released to their country. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13406

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.2.17.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Granting limited higher access
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Under exceptional circumstances, temporary access to systems classified RESTRICTED and below may be granted. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13406

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.2.18.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Controlling limited higher access
policyDefinitionGroups.description: When personnel are granted access to a system under the provisions of limited higher access they need to be closely supervised or have their access controlled such that they have access only to that information they require to undertake their duties. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13406

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.2.19.C.03.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Granting emergency access
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Emergency access to a system may be granted where there is an immediate and critical need to access information for which personnel do not have the appropriate security clearances. Such access will need to be granted by the agency head or their delegate and be formally documented. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13406

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.2.20.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Accessing endorsed or compartmented information
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Limited higher access to systems processing, storing or communicating endorsed or compartmented information is not permitted. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13406

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Using The Internet
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Personnel use Internet services in a responsible and security conscious manner, consistent with agency policies. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#Section-13449

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.3.4.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Using The Internet - Using the Internet
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies will need to determine what constitutes suspicious activity, questioning or contact in relation to their own work environment. Suspicious activity, questioning or contact may relate to the work duties of personnel or the specifics of projects being undertaken by personnel within the agency. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13456

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.3.5.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Using The Internet - Awareness of Web usage policies
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Users MUST be familiar with and formally acknowledge agency Web usage policies for system users in order to follow the policy and guidance. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13456

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.3.5.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Using The Internet - Awareness of Web usage policies
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Users MUST be familiar with and formally acknowledge agency Web usage policies for system users in order to follow the policy and guidance. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13456

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.3.6.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Using The Internet - Monitoring Web usage
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies may choose to monitor compliance with aspects of Web usage policies, such as access attempts to blocked websites, pornographic and gambling websites, as well as compiling a list of system users that excessively download and/or upload data without an obvious or known legitimate business requirement. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13456

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.3.7.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Using The Internet - Posting information on the Web
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Personnel need to take special care not to accidentally post information on the Web, especially in forums and blogs. Even Official Information or UNCLASSIFIED information that appears to be benign in isolation could, in aggregate, have a considerable security impact on the agency, government sector or wider government. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13456

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Using The Internet - Posting personal information on the Web
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Personnel need to be aware that any personal interest or other information they post on websites can be used to develop a detailed profile of their families, lifestyle, interest and hobbies in order to attempt to build a trust relationship with them or others. This relationship could then be used to attempt to elicit information from them or implant malicious software on systems by inducing them to, for instance, open emails or visit websites with malicious content. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13456

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.3.9.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Using The Internet - Peer-to-peer applications
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Personnel using peer-to-peer file sharing applications are often unaware of the extent of files that are being shared from their workstation. In most cases peer-to-peer file sharing applications will scan workstations for common file types and share them automatically for sharing or public consumption. Examples of peer-to-peer file sharing applications include Shareaza, KaZaA, Ares, Limewire, eMule and uTorrent. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13456

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 9.3.10.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Using The Internet - Receiving files via the Internet
policyDefinitionGroups.description: When personnel receive files via peer-to-peer file sharing, IM or IRC applications they are often bypassing security mechanisms put in place by the agency to detect and quarantine malicious code. Personnel should be encouraged to send files via established methods such as email, to ensure they are appropriately scanned for malicious code. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13456

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Escorting Uncleared Personnel
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Uncleared personnel are escorted within secure areas. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#Section-13489

policyDefinitionGroups.description: Cable management systems are designed to support the integration of systems across government facilities, assist maintenance and engineering changes, as well as minimise the opportunity for tampering or unauthorised changes to�cable systems. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#Section-13522

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 10.1.42.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Backbone
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The design of a backbone requires consideration of a number of criteria including the capacity of the cable to carry the predicted volume of data at acceptable speeds. An element of �future proofing� is also required as re-cabling to manage capacity issues can be costly. Fibre optic cable provides a convenient means of securing and �future proofing� backbones. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13582

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Use of Fibre Optic Cable
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Fibre optic cable is considered more secure than copper cables and provides electrical isolation of signals. Fibre will also provide higher bandwidth and speed to allow a degree of future-proofing in network design. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13582

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Cabling Standards
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Unauthorised personnel could inadvertently or deliberately access system cabling. This could result in loss or compromise of classified information. Non-detection of covert tampering or access to system cabling may result in long term unauthorised access to classified information by a hostile entity. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13582

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 10.1.45.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Cable colours
policyDefinitionGroups.description: To facilitate cable management, maintenance and security cables and conduit should be colour-coded to indicate the classification of the data carried and/or classification of the compartmented data. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13582

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Cable colours for foreign systems in New Zealand facilities
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Foreign systems should be segregated and separated from other agency systems for security purposes. Colour-coding will facilitate installation, maintenance, certification and accreditation. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13582

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 10.1.46.C.04.

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Cable groupings
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Grouping cables provides a method of sharing conduits and cable reticulation systems in the most efficient manner. These conduits and reticulation system must be inspectable and cable separations must be obvious. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13582

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Fibre optic cables sharing a common conduit
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The use of multi-core fibre optic cables can reduce installation costs. The principles of separation and containment of cross-talk and leakage must be adhered to. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13582

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Emanation Security Threat Assessments
policyDefinitionGroups.description: In order to minimise compromising emanations or the opportunity for a technical attack, a threat assessment is used to determine appropriate countermeasures. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#Section-13859

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 10.7.6.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Emanation Security Threat Assessments - Emanation security threat assessments within New Zealand
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Obtaining the current threat advice from GCSB on potential adversaries and threats and applying the appropriate countermeasures is vital in maintaining the confidentiality of classified systems from an emanation security attack. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13870

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 10.7.7.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Emanation Security Threat Assessments - Emanation security threat assessment outside New Zealand
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Fixed sites and deployed military platforms are more vulnerable to emanation security attack and require a current threat assessment and countermeasure implementation. Failing to implement recommended countermeasures and standard operating procedures to reduce threats could result in the platform emanating compromising signals which, if intercepted and analysed, could lead to platform compromise with serious consequences. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13870

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 10.7.8.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Emanation Security Threat Assessments - Early identification of emanation security issues
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The identification of emanation security controls that need to be implemented for a system at an early stage in the project lifecycle. This can significantly affect project costs. Costs are invariably greater where changes are necessary once the system had been designed or has been implemented. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13870

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 10.8.34.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Network Design, Architecture and IP Address Management - Risk Assessment
policyDefinitionGroups.description: A risk assessment is a fundamental tool in the architecture and design of a network.� https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13937

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 10.8.35.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Network Design, Architecture and IP Address Management - Security Architecture
policyDefinitionGroups.description: It is important that the principles of separation and segregation as well as the system classification are incorporated into the overall security architecture to maximise design and operational efficiency and to provide and support essential security to the network design. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13937

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 10.8.36.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Network Design, Architecture and IP Address Management - Identification of major classifications/categories of network segments
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Identified in the risk assessment, it is essential that the classification of systems is clearly identified and is apparent in all architecture and design elements and systems documentation. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13937

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 10.8.37.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Network Design, Architecture and IP Address Management - Visibility
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Clear identification and visibility of the classifications or category of a network segment is essential in minimising accidental cross-connections, incident management and in limiting the propagation of errors form one segment to others.� This also assists in network maintenance and management. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13937

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 10.8.38.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Network Design, Architecture and IP Address Management - Information Repository
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Clear documentation and records of changes to the architecture and construct of a network are essential in change management, planning, design of network modifications, incident management and maintenance of a strong security posture. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13937

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Radio Frequency and Infrared Devices
policyDefinitionGroups.description: To maintain the integrity of secure areas, only approved radio frequency (RF) and infrared devices (IR) are brought into secure areas. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#Section-13959

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.1.9.C.03.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Radio Frequency and Infrared Devices - Infrared keyboards
policyDefinitionGroups.description: When using infrared keyboards with CONFIDENTIAL or SECRET systems, drawn opaque curtains are an acceptable method of protecting windows and managing line of sight and reflected transmissions. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13974

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.1.11.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Radio Frequency and Infrared Devices - RF devices in secure areas
policyDefinitionGroups.description: RF devices pose security threat as they are capable of picking up and transmitting classified background conversations. Furthermore, many RF devices can connect to IT equipment and act as unauthorised data storage devices or bridge �air gaps�. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13974

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.1.13.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Radio Frequency and Infrared Devices - RF controls
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Minimising the output power of wireless devices and using RF shielding on facilities will assist in limiting the wireless communications to areas under the control of the agency. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-13974

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Fax Machines, Multifunction Devices and Network Printers
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Fax machines, multifunction devices (MFD�s) and network printers are used in a secure manner. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#Section-13999

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.2.3.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Fax Machines, Multifunction Devices and Network Printers - Fax machine, MFD and network printer usage policy
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Fax machines, MFDs and network printers are capable of communicating classified information, and are a potential source of information security incidents. It is therefore essential that agencies develop a policy governing their use. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14005

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.2.6.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Fax Machines, Multifunction Devices and Network Printers - Receiving fax messages
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Whilst the communications path between fax machines and MFDs may be appropriately protected, personnel need to remain cognisant of the need-to-know of the information that is being communicated. As such it is important that fax messages are collected from the receiving fax machine or MFD as soon as possible. Furthermore, if an expected fax message is not received it may indicate that there was a problem with the original transmission or the fax message has been taken by an unauthorised person. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14005

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.2.7.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Fax Machines, Multifunction Devices and Network Printers - Connecting MFDs to telephone networks
policyDefinitionGroups.description: When a MFD is connected to a computer network and a telephone network the device can act as a bridge between the networks. As such the telephone network needs to be accredited to the same classification as the computer network the MFD is connected to. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14005

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.2.8.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Fax Machines, Multifunction Devices and Network Printers - Connecting MFDs to computer networks
policyDefinitionGroups.description: As network connected MFDs are considered to be devices that reside on a computer network they need to be able to process the same classification of information that the network is capable of processing. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14005

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.2.9.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Fax Machines, Multifunction Devices and Network Printers - Copying documents on MFDs
policyDefinitionGroups.description: As networked MFDs are capable of sending scanned or copied documents across a connected network, personnel need to be aware that if they scan or copy documents at a classification higher than that of the network the device is connected to they could be causing a data spill onto the connected network. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14005

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.2.10.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Fax Machines, Multifunction Devices and Network Printers - Observing fax machine and MFD use
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Placing fax machines and MFDs in public areas can assist in reducing the likelihood that any suspicious use of fax machines and MFDs by personnel will go unnoticed. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14005

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.2.11.C.04.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Fax Machines, Multifunction Devices and Network Printers - Servicing and Maintenance
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Network and MFD printers invariably use hard disk drives, flash drives or other reusable storage which can contain copies of classified information. Any maintenance or servicing should be conducted under supervision or by cleared personnel. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14005

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.2.11.C.05.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Fax Machines, Multifunction Devices and Network Printers - Servicing and Maintenance
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Network and MFD printers invariably use hard disk drives, flash drives or other reusable storage which can contain copies of classified information. Any maintenance or servicing should be conducted under supervision or by cleared personnel. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14005

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.2.12.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Fax Machines, Multifunction Devices and Network Printers - USB Devices
policyDefinitionGroups.description: MFDs may also be equipped with USB ports for maintenance and software updates. It is possible to copy data from installed storage devices to USB devices. Any use of USB capabilities must be carefully managed. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14005

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.2.13.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Fax Machines, Multifunction Devices and Network Printers - Decommissioning and Disposal
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The use of storage media and the characteristics of electrostatic drums allow the recovery of information from such devices and components. To protect the information, prescribed disposal procedures should be followed. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14005

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Telephones and Telephone Systems
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Telephone systems are prevented from communicating unauthorised classified information. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#Section-14055

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.3.5.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Telephones and Telephone Systems - Telephones and telephone systems usage policy
policyDefinitionGroups.description: All unsecure telephone networks are subject to interception. The level of expertise needed to do this varies greatly. Accidentally or maliciously revealing classified information over a public telephone networks can lead to interception. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14063

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.3.6.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Telephones and Telephone Systems - Personnel awareness
policyDefinitionGroups.description: There is a high risk of unintended disclosure of classified information when using telephones. It is important that personnel are made aware of what levels of classified information they discuss on particular telephone systems as well as the audio security risk associated with the use of telephones. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14063

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.3.6.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Telephones and Telephone Systems - Personnel awareness
policyDefinitionGroups.description: There is a high risk of unintended disclosure of classified information when using telephones. It is important that personnel are made aware of what levels of classified information they discuss on particular telephone systems as well as the audio security risk associated with the use of telephones. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14063

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.3.9.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Telephones and Telephone Systems - Cordless telephones
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Cordless telephones have little or no effective transmission security, therefore should not be used for classified or sensitive communications. They also operate in an unlicensed part of the radio spectrum used for a wide range of other devices. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14063

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.3.10.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Telephones and Telephone Systems - Cordless telephones with secure telephony devices
policyDefinitionGroups.description: As the data between cordless handsets and base stations is not secure, cordless telephones MUST NOT be used for classified communications even if the device is connected to a secure telephony device. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14063

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.3.12.C.03.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Telephones and Telephone Systems - Off-hook audio protection
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Providing off-hook security minimises the chance of accidental classified conversation being coupled into handsets and speakerphones. Limiting the time an active microphone is open limits this threat. This is normally achieved with push-to-talk (PTT) mechanisms. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14063

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Telephones and Telephone Systems - Electronic Records Retention and Voicemail
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Voicemail and other messages and communications may fall within the legal definition of electronic records. If so retention and archive requirements are prescribed. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14063

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.3.13.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Telephones and Telephone Systems - Electronic Records Retention and Voicemail
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Voicemail and other messages and communications may fall within the legal definition of electronic records. If so retention and archive requirements are prescribed. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14063

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.3.13.C.03.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Telephones and Telephone Systems - Electronic Records Retention and Voicemail
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Voicemail and other messages and communications may fall within the legal definition of electronic records. If so retention and archive requirements are prescribed. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14063

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Mobile Telephony

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.4.9.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Mobile Telephony - Mobile device usage policy
policyDefinitionGroups.description: All mobile devices are subject to interception. The required level of expertise needed varies greatly. Accidentally or maliciously revealing classified information over mobile devices can be intercepted leading to a security breach. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14113

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.6.63.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Radio Frequency Identification Devices - Shielding
policyDefinitionGroups.description: RF shielding is designed to limit the propagation of RF signals outside of the shielded area. Shielding helps to prevent unauthorised reading, access to or modification of the RFID tag data or interfering with RFID readers. Shielding can be applied to small, individual items, such as passports and credit cards or to large elements such as shipping containers. The requirement for shielding is determined by the risk assessment and an engineering assessment. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14250

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.6.64.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Radio Frequency Identification Devices - Positioning of Tags and Readers
policyDefinitionGroups.description:
In order to minimise unnecessary electromagnetic radiation tags and readers should be carefully positioned. Care should be taken in use of RFID readers in proximity to:
Fuel, ordnance, and other hazardous materials,�
Humans and sensitive products (e.g., blood, medicine) that may be harmed by sustained exposure to RF radiation,�
Metal and reflective objects that can modify and amplify signals in unintended and potentially harmful ways, and�
Legitimate radio and Wi-Fi systems to avoid interference.
 https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14250

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.6.65.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Radio Frequency Identification Devices - Encoding and Encryption
policyDefinitionGroups.description: If an adversary reads an identifier that is encoded with a published format, such as in the EPC standard, an adversary may be able to obtain useful information such as the manufacturer or issuer of the item, as well as the type of item. Because RFID tags hold limited information and identifier formats are published in standards, it may be important to use identifier formats that do not reveal any information about tagged items or the agency using the RFID system. This will be determined in the risk assessment. Encoding schemes to limit information revealed from unauthorised scanning may include serially or randomly assigning identifiers. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14250

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.6.66.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Radio Frequency Identification Devices - Authentication
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Both an RFID reader and RFID tag share a common secret key that can be used in combination with a hash algorithm to provide one-way or mutual authentication between tag and reader. This is known as a Keyed-Hash Message Authentication Code (HMAC). When HMAC is applied to messages, it also assures the integrity of data in the messages. HMAC is not specified in any RFID standard, but the capability is generally available in vendor products. HMAC is often used where the risk of eavesdropping is high and passwords alone are considered to offer an inadequate authentication mechanism. This will be determined by the risk assessment. HMAC is also used where applications require evidence of a tag�s authenticity. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14250

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.6.67.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Radio Frequency Identification Devices - Password Management
policyDefinitionGroups.description: RFID tags generally require passwords before execution of commands such as reading and writing of tag data, memory access control, and the tag kill feature. Passwords are an important control in maintaining the security and integrity of the RFID system. Refer also to Chapter 16 � Access Control and passwords. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14250

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.6.68.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Radio Frequency Identification Devices - Temporary Deactivation of Tags
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The RF interface on some tags can be temporarily deactivated. In a supply chain application, for example, tags may be turned off to prevent unauthorised access to the tags during shipment. This feature is useful when communication between readers and a tag is infrequent allowing the tag to be activated when required but limiting vulnerability to rogue transactions if left operational for extended periods with no authorised activity. Temporary deactivation can also extend battery life in powered tags. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14250

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.6.69.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Radio Frequency Identification Devices - Incident Management
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Incident management and audit procedures, logging and time stamps help detect and manage security breaches. These are important tools in protecting systems and managing security breaches. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14250

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.6.70.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Radio Frequency Identification Devices - Disposal
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Tag disposal and recycling procedures that permanently disable or destroy sensitive data reduces the possibility that they could be used later for tracking or targeting, and prevents access to sensitive data stored on tags. In addition the continued operating presence of a tag after it has performed its intended function can pose a business intelligence or privacy risk, including tracking, targeting or access to sensitive data on the tag. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14250

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.6.71.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Radio Frequency Identification Devices - Operator Training and User Awareness
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Operator training can help ensure that personnel using the RFID system have the necessary skills and knowledge follow appropriate guidelines and policies. If HERF/HERO/HERP risks are present, appropriate security training covers mitigation techniques, such as safe handling distances. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14250

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 11.6.72.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Radio Frequency Identification Devices - Secure Spaces
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The identification of classes of tags is fundamental to managing the risks of RFID devices in secure spaces. Classes 0 and 1 pose little risk. Other classes of tag (2 to 5), however, have limited data storage capability and active tags include transmitter functionality which introduces higher levels of risk. RFID readers are, by definition, transmitters and are not permitted in secure spaces. Some exceptions may be permitted for testing, and inspection and monitoring purposes. Any such exceptions must be carefully controlled and monitored. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14250

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Product Selection and Acquisition
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Products providing security functions for the protection of classified information are formally evaluated in order to provide a degree of assurance over the integrity and performance of the product. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#Section-14398

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 12.1.30.C.03.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Product Selection and Acquisition - Evaluated product selection preference order
policyDefinitionGroups.description: In selecting products for use, agencies should note that completed evaluations provide greater assurance than those products that are still undergoing evaluation or have not completed any formal evaluation activity. This assurance gradation is reflected in the preference order for selecting security products. If an agency selects a product that is ranked lower in the preference order, the justification for this decision MUST be recorded. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14445

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 12.1.31.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Product Selection and Acquisition - Evaluated product selection
policyDefinitionGroups.description: A certified product might not meet the security requirements of an agency.  This could occur for a number of reasons, including that the scope of the evaluation is inappropriate for the intended use or the operational environment differs from that assumed in the evaluation.  As such, an agency should ensure that a product is suitable by reviewing all available documentation.  In the case of Common Criteria certified products list, this documentation includes the protection profile, target of evaluation, security target, certification report, consumer guide along with any qualifications and limitations. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14445

policyDefinitionGroups.description: An evaluation of products provides assurance that the product will work as expected with a clearly defined set of constraints. policyDefinitionGroups.description: To ensure that a product will still provide the assurance desired by the agency when used in a manner for which it was not intended, a security risk assessment MUST be conducted upon the altered configuration. policyDefinitionGroups.description: IT equipment is classified and appropriately labelled. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#Section-14507

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 12.3.4.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Product Classifying and Labelling - Classifying IT equipment
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Much of today�s technology incorporates an internal data storage capability. When media is used in IT equipment there is no guarantee that the equipment has not automatically accessed classified information from the media and stored it locally to the device, without the knowledge of the system user. As such, the IT equipment needs to be afforded the same degree of protection as that of the associated media. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14515

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 12.3.5.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Product Classifying and Labelling - Labelling IT equipment
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The purpose of applying protective markings to all assets in a secure area is to reduce the likelihood that a system user will accidentally input classified information into another system residing in the same area that is of a lower classification than the information itself. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14515

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 12.3.6.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Product Classifying and Labelling - Labelling high assurance products
policyDefinitionGroups.description: High assurance products often have tamper-evident seals placed on their external surfaces. To assist system users in noticing changes to the seals, and to prevent functionality being degraded, agencies MUST limit the use of non-essential labels. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14515

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 12.3.7.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Product Classifying and Labelling - Labelling HACE
policyDefinitionGroups.description: HACE often have tamper-evident seals placed on their external surfaces. To assist system users in noticing changes to the seals, and to prevent functionality being degraded, agencies MUST only place seals on equipment with GCSB approval. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14515

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Product Patching and Updating - Firmware updates
policyDefinitionGroups.description: As firmware provides the underlying functionality for hardware it is essential that the integrity of any firmware images or updates are maintained. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14536

policyDefinitionGroups.description: Once a cessation date for support is announced for software or IT equipment, agencies will increasingly find it difficult to protect against vulnerabilities found in the software or IT equipment as no security patches will be made available by the manufacturer after support ceases. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14536

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Product Sanitisation and Disposal
policyDefinitionGroups.description: All IT equipment is sanitised and disposed of in an approved and secure manner. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#Section-14585

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 12.6.4.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Product Sanitisation and Disposal - Sanitisation or destruction of IT equipment
policyDefinitionGroups.description: In order to prevent the disclosure of classified information into the public domain agencies will need to ensure that IT equipment is either sanitised or destroyed before being declassified and authorised for released into the public domain. Refer also to Chapter 13 - Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14592

Refer also to Chapter 13 - Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14592

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 12.6.5.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Product Sanitisation and Disposal - Disposal of IT equipment
policyDefinitionGroups.description: When disposing of IT equipment, agencies need to sanitise or destroy and subsequently declassify any media within the product that are capable of storing classified information. Once the media have been removed from the product it can be considered sanitised. Following subsequent approval for declassification from the owner of the information previously processed by the product, it can be disposed of by the agency. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14592

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 12.6.6.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Product Sanitisation and Disposal - Sanitising printer cartridges and copier drums
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Electrostatic drums can retain an image of recently printed documents providing opportunity for unauthorised access to information. Some printer cartridges may have integrated drums. Printing random text with no blank areas on each colour printer cartridge or drum ensures that no residual information will be kept on the drum or cartridge. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14592

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 12.6.7.C.02.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Product Sanitisation and Disposal - Destroying printer cartridges and copier drums
policyDefinitionGroups.description: When printer cartridges with integrated copier drums or discrete drums cannot be sanitised due to a hardware failure, or when they are empty, there is no other option available but to destroy them. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14592

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 12.6.8.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Product Sanitisation and Disposal - Disposal of televisions and monitors
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Turning up the brightness to the maximum level on video screens will allow agencies to easily determine if information has been burnt in or persists upon the screen. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14592

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 12.6.9.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Product Sanitisation and Disposal - Sanitising televisions and monitors
policyDefinitionGroups.description: All types of video screens are capable of retaining classified information on the screen if appropriate mitigation measures are not taken during the lifetime of the screen. CRT monitors and plasma screens can be affected by burn-in whilst LCD screens can be affected by image persistence which can led to LED/OLED burn-in. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14592

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 12.6.10.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Product Sanitisation and Disposal - LCD/LED, plasma and non-CRT monitor types
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Current generations of monitors incorporate controllers to manage power up/power down, manage the display, operate any USB or other ports and manage the video data stream.  The controller requires memory to operate and it incorporates some data storage capability and full write/read access to the display.  It also retains settings and configuration.  The underlying technology is often based on an FPGA and invariably requires some form of memory capability in order to operate.    Researchers have demonstrated that images can be recovered by directly accessing the controller and associated memory or analysing the orientation of the liquid crystals.In addition monitors can be compromised to actively monitor or covertly steal data and even manipulate what is displayed on the screen.  Other attacks exploiting monitors have also been demonstrated. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14592

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Supply Chain - Security validation
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Validation of the performance and security of the equipment is a vital part of the ongoing integrity and security of agency systems. policyDefinitionGroups.description: To ensure systems�are safely decommissioned and that software, system logic and data are properly transitioned to new systems or archived in accordance with agency, legal and statutory requirements. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#Section-14679

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 13.1.9.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: System Decommissioning - Agency Policy
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Information systems are often supported by service and supply contracts and may also be subject to obligations to provide a service, capability or information. Decommissioning of a system will require the termination of these contracts and service obligations. Other aspects of system decommission may be subject to security, regulatory or legislative requirements. An Agency policy will provide a comprehensive approach to system decommissioning from the inception of a system, thus facilitating the termination of supply contracts and service obligations while managing any risks to the Agency. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14694

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 13.1.10.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: System Decommissioning - Migration plan
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Once the decision to decommission a system has been taken, it is important to migrate processes, data, users and licences to replacement systems or to cease activities in an orderly fashion. It is also important to carefully plan the decommissioning process in order to avoid disruption to other systems, ensure business continuity, ensure security, protect privacy and meet any archive and other regulatory and legislative requirements. The basis of a decommissioning plan is a risk assessment. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14694

policyDefinitionGroups.description: Once the decision to decommission a system has been taken, it is important to migrate processes, data, users and licences to replacement systems or to cease activities in an orderly fashion. It is also important to carefully plan the decommissioning process in order to avoid disruption to other systems, ensure business continuity, ensure security, protect privacy and meet any archive and other regulatory and legislative requirements. policyDefinitionGroups.category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Media Handling - Classifying media connected to systems of higher classifications
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Unless connected through a data diode or similar infrastructure, there is no guarantee that classified information was not copied to the media while it was connected to a system of higher classification than the classification level of the media itself. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14734

policyDefinitionGroups.category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Media Handling - Classifying media below that of the system
policyDefinitionGroups.description: When sufficient assurance exists that information cannot be written to media that is used with a system, then the media can be treated in accordance with the handling instructions of the classification of the information it stores rather than the classification of the system it is connected to or used with. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14734

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Media Handling - Reclassifying media to a higher classification

policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Media Usage - Using media for data transfers

policyDefinitionGroups.description: Some types of media cannot be sanitised and therefore MUST be destroyed. policyDefinitionGroups.category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Volatile media sanitisation
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The following guidance applies in cases where media is to be redeployed.�When sanitising volatile media, the specified time to wait following removal of power is based on applying a safety factor to research on recovering the contents of volatile media. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14828

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 13.4.12.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Treatment of volatile media following sanitisation
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The following guidance applies in cases where media is to be redeployed.�There is published literature that supports the existence of short-term data remanence effects in volatile media. Data retention time is reported to range from minutes (at normal room temperatures) to hours (in extreme cold), depending on the temperature of the volatile media. Further, published literature has shown that some volatile media can suffer from long-term data remanence effects resulting from physical changes to the media due to continuous storage of static data for an extended period of time. It is for these reasons that TOP SECRET volatile media MUST always remain at this classification, even after sanitisation. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14828

policyDefinitionGroups.name: 13.4.13.C.01.
policyDefinitionGroups.category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Non-volatile magnetic media sanitisation
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The following guidance applies in cases where media is to be redeployed.�Both the host protected area and device configuration overlay table of non-volatile magnetic hard disks are normally not visible to the operating system or the computer�s BIOS. Hence any sanitisation of the readable sectors on the media will not overwrite these hidden sectors leaving any classified information contained in these locations untouched. Some sanitisation programs include the ability to reset devices to their default state removing any host protected areas or device configuration overlays. This allows the sanitisation program to see the entire contents of the media during the subsequent sanitisation process. https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-14828
